reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Provision of financial support for 250 Palestinian Refugees from Lebanon/Syria (children and older persons at risk), and 350 Syrian Refugee Children across Lebanon to improve access to hospital care

description.narrative:
During SAMS consultations with UN refugee health providers in Lebanon in May 2019, interventional cardiac care for PRL and PRS and limited access to urgent and non-urgent hospital care for Syrian refugees were identified as critical unmet needs, and hence is the focus of this intervention. Syrian, PRS/PRL children at risk and PRS/PRL older persons at risk residing in Beirut/Mount Lebanon, the Beka’a Valley, Akkar, T5, and South Lebanon, pre-approved according to UNRWA and UNHCR medical and vulnerability criteria, will be the direct beneficiaries of this intervention. SAMS will work with UNHCR to pay top-up contributions toward hospital invoices for registered and unregistered Syrian refugee children who require advanced hospital care for PRL/PRS requiring Open Heart Surgery and Angioplasties only, SAMS will work with UNRWA to provide top-up contributions to hospital bills for children and older persons at risk.
Upon receiving pre-approved cases from UNRWA/UNHCR, SAMS will commit a financial contribution to the hospital bill. Patients will then be able to receive care in a timely manner at the nearest hospital to their home, within the UNHCR/UNRWA network of contracted healthcare providers. SAMS will support a portion of the cost of care, along with UNHCR/UNRWA and the patient, to decrease the patient contribution of the hospital invoice. Upon discharge from the hospital, SAMS will serve as a referrals focal point for patients with post-operative complications. Patients contacting the SAMS Medical Coordinator will be put in contact with other healthcare providers to receive the necessary care, including specialist providers and those organizations that provide the comprehensive primary healthcare package. Any cost of post-operative care is outside of the scope of this project and is not included in the budget.
Aligned with the Lebanon Crisis Response Plan (LCRP), the project is designed to strengthen the existing health system, as opposed to direct service provision. Working with contracted specialist hospitals, UNRWA and UNHCR will cover the major cost of hospital invoices for improved access to hospital care for PRL, PRS and Syrian Refugees. As discussed and confirmed with UNRWA, there is a a particular need for cardiac interventions among PRL and PRS, which SAMS will support with a top-up portion to reduce the burden on the PRL and PRS patients. For Syrian refugee children at risk, and after discussing with UNHCR health sector lead, SAMS will help to reduce financial barriers to accessing hospital care for urgent and non-urgent cases as defined by UNHCR – not limited to cardiac interventions. This will decrease the financial burden on the most vulnerable Syrians, since with SAMS support they will pay little or no contribution. Rates of cost coverage for each provider (UNHCR/UNRWA/SAMS) have been agreed in the preparation of this proposal. These rates have been calculated based on the UN's existing experience and internal guidelines for implementing similar secondary care interventions, as well as SAMS’ goal to improve access to advanced health care for the greatest number of patients. Where needed, outside of funds provided by LHF, SAMS has capacity to contribute gift-in-kind (GIK) medical supplies, as well as volunteer medical specialists who may provide in-person and/or remote technical support – particularly in terms of review of existing UNHCR/UNRWA medical needs criteria, and guidance for SAMS team and their assigned patients around follow-up care.
A total of 600 individuals are expected to benefit directly: 350 Syrian refugees and 250 PRS/PRL. Of these, 50% will be female and 50% male 100% of the Syrian patients will be children, while up to 90% of PRS/PRL patients are anticipated to be older persons at risk, and a minimum of 10% will be children at risk. Of those receiving services, some 3.5% are expected to be PWDs.
